name: (3Z)-3-(2-nitrobenzylidene)-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1388

name: (3Z)-3-(2-nitrobenzylidene)-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1388
Reason: The compound has several key functional groups that influence its melting point: a nitro group attached to a benzene ring, an additional benzene ring as part of an indole structure, and a carbonyl group. The basic benzene structure has a melting point of 5.5°C. The nitro group is an electron-withdrawing group, which would typically increase the melting point due to stronger intermolecular forces like dipole-dipole interactions; for the sake of this prediction, the effect of the nitro group is estimated as +40°C. The indole structure is another aromatic system, which due to its larger size and planarity, generally contributes to an increase in the melting point; this might be around +15°C. Lastly, the carbonyl group can participate in hydrogen bonding and has a polarized double bond which often increases the melting point; its effect is estimated as +10°C. These effects are additive when predicting the melting point.

name: (3Z)-3-(2-nitrobenzylidene)-1,3-dihydro-2H-indol-2-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1388
Reason: The target compound possesses various functional groups that influence its melting point: a nitro group which is known for increasing melting point through enhanced intermolecular attractions estimated at +40°C, an indole structure that contributes robustness and planarity to the molecule estimated at +15°C, and a carbonyl group which can engage in additional polar interactions estimated at +10°C. The basic benzene unit has a melting point of 5.5°C. Therefore, the sum of effects from each functional group needs to be added to the base value of benzene to predict the melting point.
